field_edited_text.value:
39

obscured in the justifiable resentment of the
residents at not being asked to participate from
the very inception of the project. Even though
vastly improved relations were obtained in
many subsequent meetings with the residents,
they never altogether forgot what they
considered a slight.

When the Upton Urban Renewal Project was
announced, in conformance with federal
requirements for local participation, the Upton
Planning Committee was formed. That
Committee was comprised of residents, area
businessmen, and representatives of area
churches and of other organizations. The
Director of the Mayor’s Advisory Committee
on Small Business was invited to sit as a
member. Residents of the area made up the
majority of the membership and leadership.
During its regular bi-weekly and frequent
subcommittee meetings such broad subjects
were discussed as beautification, code
enforcement, traffic and transportation,
parking, health, sanitation, education,
employment, housing, recreation and business
rehabilitation.

It became obvious from these many meetings,
contrary to the view of those who would design
the ideal plan and leave it to others to execute,
that a realistic possibility for implementation
must be in clear view from the very beginning,
even if it means acceptance of less than the
ideal. The importance of community
involvement in the embryonic stages of a
proposed project should not be &nderestimated.
The delays and frustrations involved are more
than offset by the community support gained
which is a political necessity in influencing
decision makers.

In the case of the Upton Project, three
examples bear out the truth of the preceding
sentence:

1. As the Demonstration Grant study
progressed, it became increasingly obvious that
only massive urban renewal treatment could
provide the necessary means to carry out a
Town Center concept. Despite official efforts
by the Small Business Committee to include the
business area in the Upton Project, the City's
plans to include it in a subsequent project some
six to eight years in the future did not change.
However, after the Upton Planning Committee
